_meanings:
{@--4@} <ab>N.</ab> of a
Ṛṣi, the husband of Aditi and
Diti, and thus the father both of gods
and demons, (so called because he
drank {#kaSya#} ‘liquor;’ <ab>cf.</ab> {#kaSyapastasya#} 
{#putro'BUt kaSyapAnAt sa kaSyapaH .#} <ls>Mārk. P.</ls>)
[He was the son of Marīci, the son of
Brahmā. He bears a very important
share in the work of creation. 
According to Mahābhārata and other accounts,
he married Aditi and 12 other 
daughters of Dakṣa, and begot on Aditi
the twelve Ādityas. By his other
twelve wives he had a numerous and
very diversified progeny: serpents,
reptiles, birds, demons, nymphs of
the lunar constellation. He was thus
the father of gods, demons, men,
beasts, birds and reptiles-in fact
of all living beings. He is therefore
often called Prajāpati].
